638982A61CE74F0A8D4D5A1D90F0BCA0.description: Analyze ways in which natural and technological sources of electric and magnetic fields can influence society and the environment (e.g., changes in animal migration, health concerns and increased communication).

F0C9C83845DB472BBF0F03BD30AB4D61.description: Design, construct and evaluate a prototype of a technology (e.g., electric motor, generator or electromagnet) to demonstrate principles of electromagnetism.

76F6ADF57AA04497A0EE63AED2BD357B.description: Analyze the direction of positive, negative and neutral charges moving in natural (e.g., solar flares and aurorae) and man-made (e.g., particle accelerators and MRI‚Äôs) magnetic fields.

B0A3AA6F7800476084B39803C4D63A2D.description: Research the characteristics of Earth‚Äôs magnetic field, including the effects of short- and long-term changes to the field.

E25D955EF1E54A8D8F5C80830E65180B.description: Represent the direction of the magnetic field around currentinduced conductors, including linear wires and wire coils, using the right hand and/or left-hand rules.

7E565B1B556742C19AF30D01BC7C479F.description: Represent magnetic fields using magnetic field lines.

FC7361ED782D496D9ED78FFD9247105E.description: Recognize how our understanding of the interrelationships between magnetic and electric fields has led to the development of technologies such as generators and electromagnets (e.g., moving charged particles create a magnetic field, interaction of electric and magnetic fields).

058967FE95F94A34BC88DC9F356D1F4C.description: Describe current scientific thinking regarding the electromagnetic force, one of the four fundamental interactions

11157E7736BA44209472FAB117885025.description: Solve problems related to Coulomb‚Äôs law (ùêπ= ùëò{ùëû1ùëû2/ùëë2 }), including electrostatic equilibrium in one- and two-dimensions.

137E224A3F3B421BBFE4B340EBF8115A.description: Examine how the electric field strength at a point varies according to the inverse square of the distance between two charges, with reference to the equation ùê∏ = ùëòQ/ùëë^2.

8C64A90A7B9A41E098036C3663AB6386.description: Draw and describe electric field lines for like and unlike point charges and plates separated by a distance.

0D8544A870844F2596615CD53E8E571A.description: Recognize that electric fields act on point charges, including action at a distance and following the inverse-square law to determine strength of field.

917701EC52084E5AB15FD1169C05E135.description: Investigate electric and magnetic fields and their interactions with matter.

81178E6CEBC34637B8B035A63B82A5E2.description: Explore the nature of scientific collaboration and contribution in researching questions related to emerging topics such as gravitational waves and the graviton.

1467D41741504E98B42A6D529C768A1A.description: Solve problems involving gravitational field strength using ùëî = ùê∫M/ùëü2 and Newton‚Äôs law of universal gravitation (ùêπ = ùê∫ {ùëö1ùëö2/ùëü2} ).

D65BCF380D0F41CC84CF22AD84EC7DE6.description: Research how scientists use an understanding of microgravity environments to further scientific understanding in fields such as biotechnology, fluid physics, materials science, combustion science and fundamental physics.

B12CD45CBB124B9991C3C3FF17927C3E.description: Discuss the relation between common misconceptions about perceptions of weightlessness in microgravity environments and people‚Äôs understanding of gravitational field strength.

00C90C6EB9FC447897318FF716B37BB3.description: Explain variations in gravitational field strength as a function of inverse-square dependence.

B8AA0680EB6549F28C4A84D1F1925743.description: Distinguish, qualitatively and quantitatively, between weight and mass.

0DADCAF3D7DE41C984001D99DD2719F6.description: Relate gravitational field strength near Earth‚Äôs surface, and variations in that field strength, to the accepted value of acceleration due to gravity near Earth‚Äôs surface.

8944050E9B84458C9EA0D306E774A841.description: Explore phenomena such as gravitational lensing, dark matter, universal expansion and contraction and time dilation as they relate to gravitational fields within the universe.

2855C8332B264B27B2D34012B01C5D89.description: Describe the characteristics of the gravitational force and its effect on large-scale phenomena throughout the universe.

914294141F314E9AA58CDBC00E167751.description: Discuss the value of the concept of fields and field theory and the meaning of field strength in understanding the effects of noncontact forces (i.e., action at a distance).

293BBBF7056545498F01A1F74DCC1272.description: Investigate gravitational fields and their interactions with matter.

E170DB772D284FF88229A3CD6AE5D17B.description: Analyze applications (e.g., neutrino detection, Large Hadron Collider, crash test dummies and personal safety devices) of the law of conservation of momentum.

47F0C109EB7E4075B2BAADA49937EA49.description: Solve problems using the law of conservation of momentum in one- and two-dimensional interactions (e.g., head-on collisions, glancing collisions, rocket launches and explosions).

8DDAC4AE3D37447B99543B6BE868EE95.description: Conduct an experiment or simulation, including collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, to determine the extent to which momentum is conserved in elastic and inelastic collisions.

481A310813C44FB2BF7261195A91BBBE.description: Provide examples that show how momentum is or is not conserved in everyday situations.

8AC4FF9198654E6D8841757FB4B79DB2.description: Investigate how changing the net force applied to an object or the amount of time the force is applied affect the momentum of an object, with reference to the formula ùêπ‚Éó‚àÜùë°= ùëö‚àÜùë£ ‚Éó.

EFB05D4FEAF34E4B811F54B9383B7FD5.description: Derive the formula for impulse from Newton‚Äôs second law of motion.

638AD8233A4240B288EFD79D5865C16B.description: Explore how impulse and momentum concepts apply to motionrelated technologies in fields such as sports science, transportation and space science.

B2650036F382444688173A7D3C242575.description: Analyze the motion of objects and interactions between objects using momentum concepts, including the law of conservation of momentum.

3357BDF3F51B4AEAB666AC241F839265.description: Investigate the efficiency of energy transformations in various technologies with reference to useful work, friction and the production heat, sound and light.

31C2606A436746C69FD9490BA05DFC29.description: Discuss the challenges in modeling conservation of energy in reallife situations.

5F627E2EAACE47C4AD204FB6890EB4D3.description: Design and perform experiments and/or simulations, including collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, to determine the kinetic energy involved in elastic and inelastic interactions (e.g., curling stones, billiard balls, bouncing ball, seatbelts and automobile collisions).

8D1D7EB8263C4ED6B1B5498FA9C9C8A9.description: Solve problems related to kinetic, potential and total mechanical energy using relevant equations (e.g., ùëäùëä = ùêπùêπ‚Éóùëëùëë‚Éóùëêùëêùëêùëêùëêùëêùëêùëê, ùëäùëä = ‚àÜùê∏ùê∏, ùê∏ùê∏ùëòùëò = ùëöùëöùë£ùë£ ‚Éó2/2 , ùê∏ùê∏ùëùùëù = ùëöùëöùëîùëî‚Éó‚Ñé ‚Éó and ùëáùëáùëáùëáùëáùëá = ùê∏ùê∏ ùëò + ùê∏ùê∏ùëùùëù).

31B65A4A0ED84E7BA57C4EA535BB1B50.description: Explain the law of conservation of energy in terms of isolated and non-isolated systems and conservation of mechanical energy.

BF5215710B854B10A85DAA3AABA1E31D.description: Identify the properties (e.g., boundaries, inputs and outputs) of a system with respect to total mechanical energy

AC3BA32D93444684BAB47DD7F4625ABE.description: Discuss how common usage of the terms work, energy and power differ from their operational definitions in physics.

7E7DEC932CAA4A5B8E97E3D1199BFE69.description: Identify the conditions required for positive, negative and zero mechanical work and their relation to the angle between the applied force and displacement.

068BD3991A354F888C59879F2BD03000.description: Recognize work as the transfer of energy that takes place when a force acts over a displacement.

9AD0256776BE4056A502D5710943EFD8.description: Investigate the nature of mechanical energy and efficiency in mechanical systems in relation to the law of conservation of energy.

53A3BB9C24544F1DA20CEA68AAED6380.description: Examine the horizontal and vertical forces that act on a projectile throughout its trajectory.

30C4B1F304F7428B8D15BBDBC3EBADED.description: Examine the vertical and horizontal forces involved in various types of circular motion (e.g., roller coaster, Ferris wheel, merry-go-round and figure skater) with reference to the concepts of centripetal and centrifugal.

7D9305ECE83C44F7BC93F192BAE986DB.description: Explore the limitations of Newton‚Äôs laws of motion in relativistic and quantum situations (e.g., objects moving at or near the speed of light and subatomic particles)

9CCCD340FA4E47389478E7410E0CC3DE.description: Solve problems involving forces acting in one- and twodimensions using graphical (e.g., scale diagrams) and mathematical (e.g., vector components, sine law and cosine law) methods.

55B77CD83F4A4FBF9D8FDCB533E2742E.description: Predict and investigate the effect of balanced or unbalanced forces, including the effect of friction, on an object that is at rest, undergoing uniform motion or undergoing uniformly accelerated motion

BA421864205746F98948284D8E3754B8.description: Describe the effect of friction and air resistance, including terminal velocity, on objects in motion (e.g., rollercoasters, skydiving, snowboards, meteors entering Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, inclined plane situations, rolling balls, spacecraft and satellite re-entry, aircraft, race cars and artillery).

7B378D345EA8485BAA7677EB53354FD8.description: Solve problems involving force, mass and acceleration, using free-body diagrams and Newton‚Äôs second law of motion (ùêπ‚Éó = ùëöùëé‚Éó)..

0E5BBE20B9064066B4F557D320EDBDFE.description: Investigate the effect of changing the mass of an object and/or force applied to an object on the acceleration of that object.

D7D117EE1A3A40DCBE3FC30F5351DE5D.description: Discuss the importance of the concepts of inertia and inertial mass with respect to the development of Newton‚Äôs laws of motion.

5E4D200F02F24F9C9863E485BA8DDCF7.description: Provide examples of how Newton‚Äôs three laws of motion can describe the movement of objects in the real world.

9BA6DCB7EAFC4CFD81210EF343293E75.description: Pose questions related to practical examples of the effects of forces on objects.

4604190FE2394F57AEE275EC5F6ADA19.description: Analyze the effects of forces on objects undergoing uniform motion, uniformly accelerated motion and circular motion.

E31A76010C3542F5A6B297F79F150739.description: Discuss the challenges in representing real world motion using models of ideal motion, which normally treat objects as a single center of mass and which disregard frictional forces.

B971FB8BA3FB4B1B837EC1456424FE5E.description: Predict the path an object (e.g., shot put, discus, hammer throw, bolo, particles in a synchrotron and rocket undergoing gravity assisted space travel) will follow once released from uniform circular motion.

E104A293226A4A369208D90EF5FBB225.description: Describe the orbits (e.g., geosynchronous, elliptical and/or circular) of satellites and celestial bodies using uniform circular motion concepts.

875B26A2BF43438CAC16741ACB89C787.description: Determine the characteristics (e.g., speed, velocity, period, distance travelled and acceleration) of uniform circular motion.

7F8778E6E104410F99DA35515EA46524.description: Design and perform an experiment that includes collecting, analyzing and interpreting data from objects that undergo projectile motion or uniform circular motion.

E929F08E646E4650BD878626AD898B4A.description: Solve problems involving projectile motion and objects in free fall using graphical (e.g., scale diagrams) and/or mathematical (e.g., vector components, sine law and cosine law) methods

FE963300E21A414AB7F38AD84433D7D6.description: Experimentally determine the value of the acceleration due to gravity near Earth‚Äôs surface.

4E6908D279B740F885122977C0A9AFA5.description: Solve problems involving different types of motion in one- and two-dimensions, including relative motion, using graphical methods, vector analysis and kinematics equations (e.g., ùë£ùë£‚Éó= ‚àÜùëëùëë‚Éó ùë°ùë° , ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëìùëì = ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëñùëñ + ùëéùëé‚Éó‚àÜùë°ùë°, ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëìùëì2 = ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëñùëñ2 + 2ùëéùëé‚Éó‚àÜùëëùëë‚Éó, ‚àÜùëëùëë‚Éó = ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëñùëñ‚àÜùë°ùë° + 12ùëéùëé‚Éó‚àÜùë°ùë°2 and‚àÜùëëùëë‚Éó = 12 (ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëñùëñ + ùë£ùë£‚Éóùëìùëì)‚àÜùë°ùë°)

C871FCB805F746149F2452B12FA8273E.description: Critique examples of realistic and non-realistic motion in popular culture such as movies, TV shows and comics

822A7729C94B450BBE7A175F2E47F1EC.description: Provide examples of situations in which everyday objects undergo uniform motion, uniformly accelerated motion, circular motion and projectile motion.

E7B5FC1F87504B5FA192E4B538AB41CB.description: Analyze motion in one- and two-dimensions, including uniform motion, uniformly accelerated motion, circular motion and projectile motion.

C85B0C9FA0AC46889754598EDB2BF1D9.description: Analyze societal and environmental impacts of applications of nuclear technologies such as medical isotopes, food irradiation, smoke detectors, industrial radiography, pesticide tracers, nuclear weapons, nuclear reactors and nuclear waste disposal.

5628ADC592C64D86AFB613983E765257.description: Examine the process of nuclear fusion and the difficulties in harnessing nuclear fusion as an energy source.

5E12B1EFE2A34D2AA28A6A1213C7D417.description: Compare the amount and rate of energy released in various man-made fission reactions (e.g., nuclear energy production, nuclear weapons, nuclear propulsion and satellites).

A466479715BE4A939DFA9404074D4752.description: Model the process of nuclear fission, including conditions necessary for a chain reaction.

7CCCBE80202B46F2911EB204A557CC41.description: Describe the characteristics of the weak nuclear force and its role in beta decay.

C7140705CAAB4B0BB96848E980000421.description: Discuss how the difficulties in detecting effects of radiation on living things lead to lack of agreement among scientists and others about those effects.

9CDD39F5638340AB96829CD4B93780A8.description: Assess the effects of radioactivity and applications of nuclear technology on society and the environment.

956AC29AA19640DEB6CB37337AA2DF2B.description: Discuss the ongoing debates within physics regarding contradictory and differentiated interpretations (e.g., Collapse, Pilot Wave, Many Worlds and Copenhagen) of quantum mechanics.

90F033D7843040908ED9493AFE92599F.description: Explore the impact of scientific understanding of relativity on the development of technologies such as the Global Positioning System, atomic clocks and communication systems.

24056193BA3C4E29B6C9C34C61C42A9B.description: Consider the implications of inconsistent time with respect to a frame of reference (e.g., time travel and the twin paradox).

C8E62562E37449229E2A9CEA02B8AE44.description: Distinguish between the theories of general and special relativity with respect to space and time (e.g., curvature of space-time, time dilation, length contraction and relativistic mass).

9A78BB3EE8874B33B9A5850855E49AAE.description: Differentiate how Newtonian mechanics, quantum mechanics, relativity and emerging theories describe the universe on different scales.

4405E749A8874EB888330708D3FA8B37.description: Research the development of quantum mechanics and relativity, including perspectives of key scientists such as Albert Einstein, Maxwell Planck, Edwin Schr√∂dinger, Werner Heisenberg, Thomas Young and Stephen Hawking.

7A499247A8D24DFA9189C7F40D9BBA7C.description: Analyze the importance of relativistic principles and quantum mechanics in our world.

6A61334465F049A284F46EBA007DACBE.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying concept related to a Physics 30 topic.

9C2410C99A5C4E8EA4221C29A23600A3.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a topic of interest related to physics.

298A48E7D592476EAA95688E25FFE8BE.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Physics 30

49E8FAD4A7A74A878C7B7FE23008381E.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Physics 30 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data.
